Expectation1: Support each other emotionally during tough times
Situation1: One sibling has just received some very difficult news and is deeply distressed by it.
Expectation2: Adhere to professional standards and operational protocols.
Situation2: A transit authority superviO35r has just entered the cabin for an immediate and unannounced performance audit.
Story: The train hummed beneath my feet as I guided it through the tunnels, my hands steady on the controls. My phone buzzed in my pocket—three frantic messages from my stepbrother, who’d just learned our dad was in the hospital. He needed me, his words raw with fear and confusion. I wanted to call him, to be the shoulder he could lean on, just like we’d promised each other after our parents married. But just then, the supervisor stepped into the cabin, clipboard in hand, eyes sharp. “Performance audit,” he announced, watching every move I made. My heart pounded. I knew the rules: no distractions, no personal calls, absolute focus. The safety of hundreds depended on me. But my brother’s pain echoed in my mind, pulling me in two directions. I gripped the controls tighter, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing down, unsure which one I’d have to let down.
